deliberation: Considered whether the cultic expressions 'תָּרִימוּ תְרוּמָה' (lift up an offering) and 'קֹדֶשׁ ... בְכׇל־גְּבוּלָהּ' (holy in all its border) are metaphorical. In priestly Hebrew these are technical terms for sacral status and property designation, not literary figures. No metaphors, similes, personification, metonymy, or idioms beyond standard cultic vocabulary.
This verse is purely geometrical and architectural: dimensions, a square around the sanctuary, and an open space. No non-literal or figurative use of language detected.

Again this verse specifies measurements and identifies the designated area as 'קֹדֶשׁ קׇדָשִׁים' (most holy), a fixed cultic category for sacred space. Within this priestly system it functions as a technical status, not as a metaphorical comparison. No figurative language devices identified.

Describes a sacred portion of land for priestly housing and for the sanctuary. Terms like 'קֹדֶשׁ מִן־הָאָרֶץ' (a holy portion from the land) and 'מִקְדָּשׁ לַמִּקְדָּשׁ' (sanctuary for the sanctuary) are cultic-technical, not metaphorical. No metaphor, simile, personification, or idiom beyond institutional language.
Allocates a measured tract of land to the Levites. All language is spatial, quantitative, and administrative, with no non-literal or figurative phrasing.

Continues the distribution of measured land, this time for the city. The phrasing 'לְכׇל־בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל יִהְיֶה' here uses 'house of Israel' in a distributive, literal-collective sense for the nation; it is a conventional designation of the people, but functioning as the normal name of the group. I reserve metonymy analysis for places where the 'house' concept is more salient. No clear figurative devices identified.

Describes the prince's allotment with directional language ('מִפְּאַת־יָם יָמָּה ... מִגְּב֥וּל יָם אֶל־גְּב֥וּל קָדִימָה'). Considered whether this is a merism (west to east for the whole), but here it literally defines the longitudinal extent of his domain, not a rhetorical totality statement. No figurative language.

Most of the verse is literal: the land as the prince's holding and the end of defrauding the people. However, the phrase 'בֵּית־יִשְׂרָאֵל' ('the house of Israel') is a standard metonymic designation where a 'house' (household) stands for a kinship group or nation. Here it clearly labels the tribes collectively by a domestic/lineage term.

target: the people of Israel as a nation, organized by tribes
vehicle: a "house" understood as a household or family unit
ground: a house gathers, shelters, and identifies the members belonging to it
the way a dwelling or household label represents all its members
using a concrete house term to stand for a social group
posture: distribution of land "to the house of Israel by its tribes"
instances.explanation: The expression 'house of Israel' uses a domestic term ('house/household') to stand metonymically for the entire nation, conceptualizing Israel as one extended household.

deliberation: Looked for non-literal rebuke language. Found (1) 'רַב־לָכֶם' as a fixed idiomatic rebuke meaning 'enough!' rather than a literal statement about quantity, and (2) 'הָרִימוּ גְרֻשֹׁתֵיכֶם מֵעַל עַמִּי', which pictures oppressive evictions as a physical load resting 'upon' the people that must be 'lifted off'. That second phrase blends idiomatic usage with a load/burden metaphor of oppression.

vehicle: the phrase 'it is much for you' (רַב לָכֶם) used idiomatically
ground: the idea that their wrongdoing has exceeded an acceptable limit
excess in moral behavior conceptualized as having 'too much' of something
using quantitative excess to express moral boundary transgression
instances.explanation: The collocation 'רַב־לָכֶם' functions as an idiomatic exclamation meaning 'That is enough!' or 'No more!', drawing on quantity language but used as a conventional rebuke rather than a literal statement about how much they have.

instances.english_text: Put a stop to your evictions of My people (lit. 'lift up/remove your expulsions from upon My people')
target: the rulers’ practice of dispossessing and driving out God’s people
vehicle: a heavy load resting on someone that is lifted off
ground: oppressive policies are experienced as a weight or burden pressing on the people
ending oppression is like lifting a weight off someone’s back
using physical pressure and relief to conceptualize social exploitation and its cessation
posture: command to remove unjust practices from 'upon' God’s people
instances.explanation: By saying 'remove (lift up) your expulsions from upon My people', the text portrays the princes' evictions as a burden pressing down on the people that must be lifted away, an oppression-as-burden metaphor expressed in an idiomatic verbal phrase.

deliberation: The triad 'מֹאזְנֵי־צֶדֶק וְאֵיפַת־צֶדֶק וּבַת־צֶדֶק' attributes 'צֶדֶק' (righteousness/justice) to weighing scales and measures. This goes beyond physical description to map a moral-legal quality onto commercial instruments, a conventional moral metaphor (and mild personification) for honest trade.

instances.english_text: Have honest balances, an honest ephah, and an honest bath (lit. 'balances of righteousness, an ephah of righteousness, and a bath of righteousness')
target: commercial transactions and the use of weights and measures
vehicle: righteousness/justice applied to physical measuring instruments
moral-legal quality of being just or upright
ground: accurate, non-deceptive measures correspond to morally right behavior
honesty in trade is like righteousness in court, hence 'righteous' weights
mapping ethical integrity onto physical tools to stress their moral significance
posture: command to ensure fair trading practices
instances.explanation: By calling scales and measures 'of righteousness', the verse metaphorically (and mildly personifies them) as morally upright, using the vocabulary of judicial righteousness to characterize economic honesty.

deliberation: Explains the equivalence between ephah, bath, and ḥomer. All terms and relationships are strictly mathematical and technical. No figurative extensions, evaluative adjectives, or anthropomorphisms here.
Defines shekel-weight in gerahs and how various shekel amounts count as a mina. Again, all language is numerical and technical. No metaphor, simile, idiom, or other figurative device is employed.
Specifies the exact fraction of an ephah to be given from grain as a contribution. This is legal-cultic prescription with numeric specificity. No non-literal or figurative language is used.
Regulates the amount of oil due, measured by the bath and ḥomer. Though the Hebrew is somewhat technical/obscure, it is about measurement, not image. No figurative language detected.

Gives the ratio of animals from the flock for offerings 'to make expiation for them'. Within priestly-cultic discourse, 'כִּפֵּר עֲלֵיהֶם' is a technical term for ritual atonement, not here used as a stylized metaphor. The verse otherwise lists offerings and ratios. No distinct literary figures identified.

States that 'כֹּל הָעָם הָאָרֶץ' (all the people of the land) shall participate in the contribution. This is a comprehensive description of the populace, but functions straightforwardly, not as a merism or synecdoche beyond normal collective reference. No specific figurative construction singled out.

Most of the verse is literal, listing types of offerings and assigning responsibility to the prince. However, the phrase 'לְכַפֵּ֖ר בְּעַ֥ד בֵּֽית־יִשְׂרָאֵֽל' uses 'house of Israel' again as a conventional metonymy for the people of Israel, casting the nation as a household that needs expiation.

target: the collective people of Israel who require expiation
vehicle: a 'house' or household as a social unit
ground: a house stands for everyone who belongs to it and shares its fate
the way a family is identified by its 'house' name maps onto national identity
using a concrete household image to denote the entire people as one unit
posture: cultic responsibility of the prince to provide offerings
instances.explanation: The expression 'house of Israel' employs a domestic term to stand metonymically for the entire people, conceptualizing the nation as a single household on whose behalf atonement is made.

deliberation: Instructs taking a flawless bull to 'חִטֵּאתָ אֶת־הַמִּקְדָּשׁ' (cleanse/purge the sanctuary). Although cleansing sin/impurity from a building is conceptually rich, in priestly language this is a technical description of ritual purification, not used as a literary metaphor here. No separate figurative device isolated.

Describes applying blood to architectural elements (doorposts, corners, gate posts). These are ritual directions about spatial loci of purification; no metaphor, simile, personification, or idiom beyond the ritual system.

Commands a similar ritual on the seventh day 'מֵאִישׁ שֹׁגֶה וּמִפֶּתִי וְכִפַּרְתֶּם אֶת־הַבָּיִת' (for someone who erred or was ignorant, and you shall purge the house). Here 'the house' is the temple complex; the atonement language is cultic-technical as in Levitical law, not deployed as a fresh figure of speech. No distinct figurative expression singled out.
Describes timing and basic observance of Passover and unleavened bread. The terms 'הַפָּסַח' and 'מַצּוֹת' are names of rituals/foods, not used metaphorically here. No figurative language detected.

States that the prince will provide a bull as a purgation offering for himself and the people. The language is straightforward cultic instruction; no metaphors, similes, or idioms beyond technical sacrificial vocabulary.

Lists numbers and types of animals for daily burnt and purgation offerings during the festival. The number seven has symbolic resonance but here functions as prescribed quantity rather than as an explicit figure of speech. No discrete figurative constructions identified.
Specifies the grain offering amounts and oil proportion per animal. Entirely technical and quantitative; no non-literal language or imagery.

Describes offerings at the seventh-month festival with 'כָאֵלֶּה' (like these) referring back to previously specified sacrifices. This 'like these' is simple anaphoric comparison, not a developed simile or metaphor. No distinct figurative device is present.
